data.text: Is the Tailfin Rack Worth Buying?
Is the tailfin rack worth it?
Yes, definitely. No getting away from its expensive but it’s very good. I also have the mini panniers for mine and I’m happy with the setup as I don’t like bar bags so for me it works well
data.author: Matt Watts

data.text: As above. Best investment I’ve made. I have two and two sets of panniers. They’re tough and light and the connections are rugged and well thought out. They’re a great company too.
data.author: John Millward

data.text: I agree they are a good company and a great product, but what is the main benefit over a regular rear rack with the same 3 connection points. Probably not weight so is it just looks and aero? I want to get one by the way so looking for the right excuse 🤣
data.author: Steve Chopper

data.text: I think the main difference is a 'proper' rack allows use of full sized panniers and the tailfin is often used to just stabilise a seat pack. Horses for courses I guess.
data.author: Giustino Clementi

data.text: The aeropack also allows for full size panniers…
data.author: John Millward
John Millward

data.text: in practical terms, they’re lighter, but in real terms, they’re just damn cool
data.author: John Millward

data.text: Did you lads go carbon or alloy?
data.author: Matthew Lee

data.text: I have one of each of the aeropacks. I bought the carbon and then a year later an alloy when they added the mounting points on the uprights.
data.author: John Millward

data.text: I went for the carbon. The only thing I changed was to later purchase the longer seat post attachment which allows me slightly more room to open the bag as sets it further back
data.author: Matt Watts

data.text: ahh ok so I was wondering about which top stay to go with cheers Matt
data.author: Matthew Lee

data.text: Absolutely yes
data.author: Chris Roberts
Graham Minshall

data.text: Yes it is. Once you get over the shock of the price. But its a great bit of kit. Far better than a back pack or seat pack.
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text: I agree with you, but what about a different type of rack even
data.author: Richard Barrett

data.text: I think the difference in weight between the alloy and carbon one is about the weight of an egg.
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text: yeah carbon not worth the extra money, I agree.
data.author: Chris Pugh

data.text: Nope. You'd save more weight by keeping off cake for week
data.author: Richard Barrett

data.text: But who the F wants to live like that…
data.author: John Millward

data.text: Nothing feels better than thin feels, especially in the sack
data.author: Richard Barrett

data.text: Exactly 🤣
data.author: Andrew Weaver

data.text: each to their own mate 😉
data.author: John Millward

data.text: Just bought one, I went for a separate alloy rack without pannier mounts & trunk bag. Not ridden with it yet, but it's a high quality piece of kit. I'll be using it for NC500 trip soon.
data.author: Andrew Weaver

data.text: My frame was too small to get it to work. Ended up going aeroe spider rack.
data.author: Kirsty Cambridge

data.text: Yeah it’s really really good, extremely well engineered. Mine fits like a glove, don’t even hear a squeak or rattle
data.author: Chris Pugh

data.text: Tubus rear racks are a lot cheaper and are highest quality bombproof items and can be used with a lightweight dry sack and/or panniers....and you can have a huge choice of panniers, such as full blown big ortliebs or ultra lightweight revelate designs nano panniers at 465g a pair!
data.author: Tim Evans

data.text: I have both Tubus and Tailfin and they are both excellent. The advantage with Tailfin for me is that I have 8 bikes and I can move the Tailfin from one to another in 10 seconds. Or I can remove it if I dont want a rack on at all.
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text: ....to be fair, the tubus only has 4 x M5 Allen bolts fixing it to the frame, so it’s pretty quick and easy to remove..
data.author: Tim Evans

data.text: . For sure. But the Tailfin is a bit like Di2. You dont need it but it is so nice when you have it. Its a bit of luxury and I deserve it. 😁
data.author: Steve Lindley
